messageBody:
Robert Watkins wrote:
> J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> > Robert Watkins wrote:
> > > One test per class makes it easy to find tests that may
> > > be affected by a feature change. This makes it easy to
> > run localised tests.
> >
> > In my experience, it doesn't. It does, however, make it
> > /look/ like it's easy to find tests that may be affected
> > by a feature change. You really don't know until you run
> > the tests, anyway.
>
> Yes. I don't advocate the "test class per production class"
> pattern. However, that's the reason I keep being given when
> I suggest introducing new test classes.
>

> One smell I hate is setup code that's only used for a few
> tests in a test class; that's something asking to be split
> up into multiple test classes.

Yes. Even worse: two possibly overlapping, but often disjoint, sets of
test fixture objects in the same test case class. Some tests use fixture
A and others use fixture B. Why not put those in separate test case
classes for clarity?

I wonder whether _xUnit Automation Patterns_ plans to talk about issues
like these. If not, then I should consider writing a few more recipes.
--
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
